CORPORATE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE APPROACHES

At this facility, Illinois-American Water Company handles chlorine for the purpose of disinfecting and treating drinking water.  The hazards of chlorine make it necessary to employ certain safety precautions in its use and handling to reduce the likelihood of human and environmental exposure in both the workplace and community.  
It is Illinois-American Water Company's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety is inherent on the manner that covered process chemicals are handled and used, the safety devices employed in the design of the feed system, as well as operating procedures and training of employees.

The Emergency Action Plan is based on OSHA Standards 29CFR1910.38,  29CFR1910.120, and on experience gained from community drills.

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Chlorine: Greenish-yellow gas with a pungent irritating odor.  Chlorine is liquified under pressure but is used as a gas at ambient temperature.  Illinois-American Water Company uses chlorine gas for water disinfection.
The maximum amount of chlorine stored at the San Koty facility is 22,000 pounds.  The chlorine is delivered by truck in 1-ton cylinders. Liquid chlorine is evaporated into gas in the cylinder.  The gas is fed by vacuum into the flow stream and metered through a chlorinator. 

Senior management is committed to the safe operation of our facilities and cognizent of the impact any deviation in processes might have on the surrounding communities.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility and process uses design codes and standards from the Chlorine Institute, Wallace and Tiernan Manuals, American National Standards Institute, American Society for Testing and Materials, and applicable state codes and regulations.  
The vacuum system by which chlorine is fed is designed to close the regulator and s

hut the feed of chlorine off at the cylinder if a leak in the feed process develops downstream of the cylinder. 
A scrubber stack has been installed which will absorb and neutralize up to one ton of chlorine in the event of a catastrophic release incident.  The scrubber will activate automatically when the concentration of chlorine in the chlorine storage or feed room reaches 3 ppm.  When activated, it must be manually shut off unless chlorine is detected at the exhaust, in which case it will automatically shut down to contain the release.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

We have had no reportable accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The written emergency response program as mentioned in the opening paragraph incorporates an ongoing training program.  Fire Department inspections/tours are conducted annually, verifying on-site chemicals, storage locations, chemical hazards, special instructions and requirements.  Drills at the company are coordinated with the local fire department.  Public notification is handled in accordance with our Emergency Action Plan.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Although there are no immediate plans for changes to improve safety at this facility, we constantly review advancements in safety and process technology in the continuing pursuit to provide a safer workplace and community. This is evidenced by the recent installation of the chlorine scrubber.
